channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Jeanine Pirro: I'm the U.S. attorney for D.C. These three laws are detrimental to making our capital safe.
item.description: Jeanine Pirro: The fight to make D.C. safe and beautiful

item.title: Who gets Kennedy Center Honors under Trump? George Strait, Kiss and Michael Crawford being eyed.
item.description: The arts complex’s marquee awards ceremony may see significant changes as President Donald Trump continues to overhaul the institution he took over in February.

item.title: National Guard to deploy in D.C. tonight, White House says, a day after Trump announced federalization of city police force
item.description: A White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the administration, said the Guard is expected to “begin being on the streets starting tonight.” A small number of the about 800 National Guard members who are expected to be a part of the mission had been mobilized as of Tuesday afternoon, defense officials said, with more expected in coming days.

item.title: White House announces more aggressive review of Smithsonian museums
item.description: In a letter, White House officials said they would focus "on Americanism" in a review of the Smithsonian’s exhibition text, curation, exhibition planning and collections, starting with eight museums.

item.title: Texas Republicans say they will start second House session on congressional maps this week, pressuring absent Democrats to return
item.description: Republicans said Tuesday they would begin another special legislative session Friday to redraw the state’s maps in favor of their party, aiming to force Democrats to quickly return or commit to remaining away for another month.

item.title: CDC shooter expressed discontent with coronavirus vaccines before firing hundreds of bullets at headquarters Friday, officials say
item.description: The assault on the Atlanta headquarters of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has left many employees angry at Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for his criticism of the agency and false claims about vaccines.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: How to face people’s questions after twin pregnancy loss?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: How to face people’s questions after twin pregnancy loss?

item.title: Dial-up memories in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Inflation held steady in July, as the full effects of Trump’s tariffs have yet to take hold
item.description: President Donald Trump’s tariffs are lifting consumer prices in some parts of the economy, according to new Labor Department data, but less than analysts predicted.

item.title: Pentagon plan would require hundreds of National Guard members to be ready around the clock to quell civil unrest
item.description: The Trump administration is evaluating plans that would establish a “Domestic Civil Disturbance Quick Reaction Force,” with 600 troops on standby at all times to deploy in as little as one hour, according to internal Pentagon documents reviewed by The Washington Post.

item.title: Trump’s D.C. crackdown. Pentagon plan. Tariff delay. Slain journalists. CDC shooting. Tropical storm. Taylor Swift. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: White House delays sharper tariffs on Chinese imports for 90 days
item.description: Trade negotiators say they want more time to work out a deal to avoid tariffs as high as 145 percent on Chinese products. The new pause would expire Nov. 9.

item.title: Trump to nominate Bureau of Labor Statistics critic E.J. Antoni to run the agency after he fired its previous chief
item.description: If confirmed by the Senate, Antoni, an economist at the Heritage Foundation, would replace Erika McEntarfer, whom Trump fired this month after a bleak report revised spring jobs figures downward.

item.title: ‘An extraordinary escalation’: What Trump’s police takeover means for D.C.
item.description: On Monday, President Donald Trump announced that he would nationalize the D.C. police and deploy the D.C. National Guard in the city.

item.title: D.C. mayor calls Trump’s federal takeover of the city’s police department ‘unsettling and unprecedented’
item.description: Mayor Muriel E. Bowser (D) said that while President Donald Trump can deploy the National Guard, D.C.’s police chief remains in control of its force. “Chief Pamela Smith is the chief of the Metropolitan Police Department, and its 3,100 members work under her direction,” she said. Trump said that 800 National Guard members have been activated, and there will be “much more if necessary, much more.”

item.title: One dead, two missing and dozens injured in explosion at U.S. Steel plant near Pittsburgh
item.description: Officials sent 15 ambulances to the site of the explosion at U.S. Steel Clairton Coke Works, which sits along the Monongahela River.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Parent concerned about 30-year-old daughter’s lax housekeeping
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Parent concerned about 30-year-old daughter’s lax housekeeping

item.title: Trump to place D.C. police under federal control and deploy National Guard to city’s streets, vowing a crackdown on violent crime
item.description: President Donald Trump says he’s ordering the National Guard to assist the D.C. police in combatting carjackings and other violent crimes. The move has raised concerns among city officials.

item.title: Judge denies Justice Department’s request to release Ghislaine Maxwell grand jury transcripts
item.description: The ruling by a New York federal judge comes after a similar rejection by a federal judge in Florida for Jeffrey Epstein-related grand jury transcripts.

item.title: What happened to the juice in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Trump vs. D.C. Putin meeting. 2028 contenders. Palestinian state. Working moms. Sunscreen. ‘AI slop.’ Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Nvidia, AMD agree to pay U.S. government 15% of AI chip sales to China
item.description: The chipmakers have agreed to pay the cut to obtain export licenses for China, according to two people familiar with the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity as they were not authorized to discuss the matter in public. The arrangement is highly unusual, with U.S. tech export controls usually based on national security imperatives rather than whether they can raise funds for Washington.

item.title: 8 scenic road trips to explore America this summer
item.description: These drives deliver volcanoes, parks, lakes and striking views all over the country.

item.title: FBI agents dispatched to fight local crime in D.C., while Trump vows to 'immediately' clear out the city’s homeless
item.description: The unusual moves come as the president, who is planning a news conference for Monday on the issue, warns of a federal government takeover of the nation’s capital that he says would be as aggressive as his immigration crackdown.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: A family opened a South Dakota town’s first bookstore. A bathroom bill is driving them away.
item.description: The Phelans ran the only bookstore in Vermillion. They sold it and moved after a new law would have required their daughter to use a boy’s bathroom.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Birds kept dropping dead in D.C. A biologist cracked the case.
item.description: A call led to a weeks-long investigation and a new discovery in the District.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: For 30 years, I’ve been ‘nice’ to my in-laws. I’m tired.
item.description: Ask Sahaj: For 30 years, I’ve been ‘nice’ to my in-laws. I’m tired.

item.title: White House and IRS officials clashed over sharing immigrants’ tax data before the agency head was ousted, people familiar say
item.description: The tax agency said Friday it wouldn’t tell immigration authorities whether people had claimed the earned income tax credit, citing privacy protections, the people told The Washington Post. Later that day, Billy Long — a former Republican member of Congress — was on his way out.

item.title: Teen kayakers made the first descent down a sacred river recently freed from its dams. The Post followed their 30-day odyssey.
item.description: The removal of four dams on the Klamath River, which flows from the Cascade Mountains in Oregon to the Pacific coast of California, was a long-sought triumph. The journey down the river would also be a monumental achievement — if the group of Indigenous youth could pull it off.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Zelensky rejects Trump’s suggestion that Ukraine cede territory to Russia as Vance prepares to meet Ukrainian officials
item.description: The U.K. and U.S. are hosting a meeting of European and Ukrainian national security advisers, hours after President Trump confirmed he would meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin next week.

item.title: Trump to meet with Putin in Alaska on Aug. 15, setting stage for Ukraine peace talks
item.description: The president said any deal between Russia and Ukraine would include “some swapping of territories to the betterment of both” countries.

item.title: Texas attorney general files lawsuit to remove fleeing Democrats from office
item.description: Attorney General Ken Paxton (R) filed a lawsuit to remove 13 of the more than 50 Democrats who left the state to block a GOP effort to redraw the congressional map. The move escalates a tense showdown over redistricting ahead of the midterm elections.

item.title: James Lovell dies at 97. He commanded the troubled Apollo 13 spacecraft and was played by Tom Hanks in a Hollywood film.
item.description: In 1970, Lovell shepherded Apollo 13 on its lunar voyage, including a perilous journey back to Earth after an oxygen tank exploded. “Houston, we’ve had a problem,” Lovell told Mission Control as the ordeal transfixed the world. Apollo 13 became a saga of mythological proportions, especially after the film that starred Tom Hanks as Lovell.

item.title: Trump will replace IRS Commissioner Billy Long; Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will run tax agency in the interim
item.description: Long, a former Republican member of Congress, had little tax policy background. It wasn't clear when a new full-time IRS chief would be named.

item.title: Smithsonian restores Trump to impeachment display in National Museum of American History exhibit but makes slight changes
item.description: The restoration comes after The Washington Post reported that President Donald Trump’s name had been removed from the exhibit’s temporary placard as part of a Smithsonian content review prompted by White House pressure.

item.title: Justice Dept. subpoenas N.Y. Attorney General Letitia James about Trump fraud probe
item.description: One of the subpoenas focused on James’s successful civil fraud case against Donald Trump and his real estate empire, which resulted in a judge ruling in 2024 that Trump and his company needed to pay $450 million in fines, people familiar with the probe said. A second subpoena suggested that the Justice Department is looking into James’s high-profile litigation against the National Rifle Association, which led to court-mandated changes for the group, they said.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Israel’s plan. Tariff impacts. Election fights. Hurricane season. Instagram Map. Weight-loss pills. Female umpire. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Israel’s security cabinet approves plan for military to occupy Gaza City
item.description: The decision comes after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Thursday that his government intends to take military control of the entire Gaza Strip.

item.title: A Senate staffer who survived a stabbing in 2023 could have been the GOP’s voice on crime. His faith intervened.
item.description: Phillip Todd, an aide to Sen. Rand Paul (R-Kentucky), was nearly killed in a random attack in D.C. He took two years to figure out what he wanted to say.

item.title: Judge orders temporary halt to construction at Alligator Alcatraz immigrant detention center in Florida
item.description: The ruling by U.S. District Court Judge Kathleen Williams came after a two-day hearing in a lawsuit filed by environmental groups and joined by the Miccosukee Tribe of Indians.

item.title: Trump will nominate White House economic adviser Stephen Miran to sit on Federal Reserve board through January
item.description: Miran is the chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers and served in the Treasury Department in Trump's first term. Trump announced the move on social media Thursday.

item.title: The economy is cracking. This trend is most alarming.
item.description: The economy is cracking. This trend is most alarming.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Heartbroken dad wants to approach his daughter about her weight
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Heartbroken dad wants to approach his daughter about her weight

item.title: The trains are not running on time in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Trump’s tariffs. Tulsi Gabbard. Human rights. Army base shooting. Alzheimer’s clue. Nuclear power. Heathy potatoes. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump’s tariffs take effect, potentially upending global trade and prices
item.description: The president has already announced frameworks of trade agreements with roughly a dozen of the country’s closest trading partners, including the United Kingdom, the European Union, Japan and South Korea. But goods from nations with which the U.S. does hundreds of billions of dollars of trade, such as India, Switzerland and South Africa, will see new taxes of up to 39 percent, with India’s rate set to jump to 50 percent in three weeks. Economists say the sweeping new taxes on imports will likely get passed on to U.S. consumers and businesses.
